posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of your text:

I'm wondering if a slip ring requires 40A or matches the recommended wire gauge for its amp ratings. I understand that these currents are safe for short periods, but the rules aren't clear on whether the maximum estimated amp rating must match the breaker on the circuit. I assume a 20A slip ring could work with a 40A breaker since 12-gauge wire handles 40A, though I'm unsure how inspectors would view this setup.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: An inspector would invoke R623 and ask if it’s appropriate to send 40A through a 20A device. Short answer, it isn’t.

posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked: Then why do we send 40A through 20A wire (actually up to 80)

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: There’s precedent in other parts of the rules to use “any rating,” such as R802, so if you could find a slip ring rated 20A continuous, 40A intermittent, I think you’d prevail with an inspector that that was okay downstream of a 40A breaker. (Although that’s unsound on an engineering basis generally, these robots just have to not catch fire for 2.5 minutes of operation.) Iron

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
The text is: EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. The text is:
PixL:

Then why do we send 40a through 20a wire (actually up to 80)

There’s an explicit provision for that in the rules (R622). The 20A rating is an NEC rating for continuous use (defined as drawing the maximum current over 3 or more hours, IIRC) including inside a wall without airflow and these robots run about 1% as long as that and the robot wires usually have pretty good airflow around them and intermittent currents.

Edit: the NEC limit is actually 30A for 12AWG THHN/XHHW/USE-2 wiring, derated to 80% of that (24A) for continuous loads. We often short-hand the rating of 12AWG wire to be 20A because that’s the size breaker that we’re allowed to land NM-B (“Romex”) cables on. That’s because NM-B is only rated to 60°C, while THHN/XHHW has a higher temp rating for the conductor’s insulation (90°C) in dry locations.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: The THHN/XHHW material offers a higher temperature rating (90°C) for conductor insulation in dry environments compared to FRC standards. However, applying this rating practically is rare because terminations typically cannot withstand such elevated temperatures. In FRC competitions, there have been cases where specific components, like an image linked here (from a PDF titled 'FRC2022RapidReact-QandAExport.pdf'), were used successfully. One notable example involves REV, a company, which managed to 're-rate' a commercially available component (COTS), allowing its 90°C rating to apply universally across all instances, regardless of the manufacturer. A reminder that questions related to Q&A often pertain to a single season, though their practicality may persist over time.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Then why do we send 40a through 20a wire (actually up to 80)  
It’s a good lesson in what ratings mean  
Wires will pass pretty much whatever current you push through them that’s not the point of the rating The real question is when does something bad happen?  
Badness is much more a function of the insulation’s failure modes and the environment over the gauge of the conductor IE I can put a metric ton of current through 18AWG wire as long as it’s cooled with a nice non-conductive oil jacket  

Here’s a 30A slip ring possibly good enough? Of note it brings me great joy that the second google result for “40A slip ring” points back to an FRC question:  

d1c67a5df8dbac4372e47ffeb6018f2e9ecbcf75.png

link_counts.title: Taidacent 2 Wires 15A 20A 30A 40A 60A Slip Ring Collector Ring Rotary Electrical Contact (30A) - Amazon.com

posts.cooked: Here’s a 30A slip ring, potentially good enough? If you’re okay with using a brushed motor, current-limiting the motor to 30A phase current (or however the intermittent rating is) and not adding any sensors (no feedback control), then it’s feasible. However, slip rings aren’t practical for FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) because they require wires rated for FRC current levels, which are scarce since manufacturers don't supply them. Usually, power and signal slip rings don’t offer wires beyond 10A. While platforms like Moflon or Senring are worth checking, I haven’t found any suitable under $600 due to tariffs affecting Chinese imports.

link_counts.title: Slip Rings - Standard In Stock & Custom Solutions - MOFLON
Slip Ring | Rotary Unions Solution Manufacturer_Senring

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Taxes and tariffs don't exceed the $600 limit. The blue box on the link highlights rule R301.

Many distributors have increased costs directly in response to the tariffs, which are included within the cost cap. Even if an item doesn't ship from China, some part of its supply chain often does, causing a significant cost increase.
